['Ponytail - A long lock or bunch of hair secured at the back of the head with an elastic band.', 'Bun - A coiled hairstyle formed by tying a section of hair into a circular shape and pinning it in place.', 'Braid - Hair woven together side-by-side to form a plait or interlaced pattern, often gathered at the back of the head.', 'Chignon - A knot of hair formed by twisting and coiling locks into an elaborate bun on top of the head.', 'Dutch braid - A type of braid where strands are added to each side instead of below, creating a raised effect along with the scalp.', 'French braid - Similar to a Dutch braid but with strands being incorporated above rather than below for a smooth, integrated look.', 'Crimping - Creating crimped or textured hair by using heated rollers and securing the ends of the locks tightly in place.', 'Updo - A hairstyle where most or all of the hair is styled up on top of the head, often including braids, twists, or curls.', 'High ponytail - A classic style involving pulling a section of hair back and securing it at the crown with an elastic band, higher than traditional variations.', 'Low ponytail - Similar to a high ponytail but positioned lower on the nape of the neck for a subtler look.', 'Headband - A thin band that can be worn around the hairline or underneath hairstyles like buns and updos, often used as an accessory.', 'Clips - Small hair fasteners in various designs and sizes to hold sections of hair back from the face.', 'Bobby pins - Round-toothed hairpins designed to grip and secure hair by slipping into strands discreetly.', 'Hair elastics - Ribbon-like bands used for gathering and holding hair in styles like buns, half-up hairstyles, or ponytails.', 'Chignon holder - A decorative accessory designed to keep a chignon secure and styled neatly on the head.', 'Hair spray - Aerosol product used for setting and securing hair in place after styling.', 'Head wrap - Not a direct lock of hair, but a way to tie or gather loose hair into a fashionable scarf-like accessory that wraps around the head.', 'Pigtails - When twisted, braided or otherwise shaped and secured on each side atop the head for individual locks.', 'Hairband - Similar to headbands but can be made of various materials like fabric or metal bands; used in styling hair by gathering it into a ponytail or bun.', 'Cornrows - A traditional African braiding style where the hair is tightly interwoven close to the scalp, often forming geometric patterns along with the skin rather than lock of hair specifically.']

to rub hard in order to clean something thoroughly', 'Soap - a substance used for washing and cleaning, typically made from the sodium salt of fatty acids', 'Detergent - a chemical that cleans dirt and grease off dirty surfaces or clothes when mixed with water', 'Sponge - an absorbent natural cellular structure often used in bathing, cooking, cleaning, or painting', 'Bubbles - small pockets of gas enclosed by liquid or a solid film, typically formed on the surface of soapy water during washing', 'Suds - foam produced when soap is mixed with water while being agitated ', 'Foam - frothy mass that forms on or in a liquid', 'Shampoo - a substance used for cleaning hair, typically in the form of a liquid applied to wet hair and then rinsed out', 'Dishw Written down: Create an extensive list of 20 words related to "Wash" that include both common household items and more specialized tools or chemicals', 'Scrub - To vigorously rub an object to remove dirt or grime with a brush or sponge.', 'Detergent - A chemical used for cleaning that breaks down stains and dirt in water.', 'Fabric softener - An additive designed to make fabrics feel softer after washing.', 'Bleach - A chemical compound, often diluted with water, used to whiten or disinfect surfaces.', 'Brush - A tool with bristles used for cleaning surfaces, teeth, hair, etc.', 'Dishwasher - An appliance designed to wash dishes and utensils automatically using water and detergent.', 'Enzymes - Biological molecules that act as catalysts in the breakdown of various substances during laundering or cleaning.', 'Softening agent - A chemical added to laundry products to impart softness to fabrics, often through conditioning and antistatic properties.', 'Agitator - An arm-like component that swirls water and cleansers in a washing machine drum during the wash cycle.', 'Rinse aid - A chemical additive designed to improve the rinsing action of hot water, helping clothes dry faster without spots.', 'List 25 technical terms related to autoregressive models and their applications, ensuring that each term is accompanied by a brief explanation of its relevance within the context of autoregression.', 'Autoregression (AR) - A time series model predicting future data points on the basis of past values in the series.', 'Autocorrelation - The correlation of a signal with a delayed copy of itself; crucial for identifying AR order.', 'Stationarity - A property indicating that statistical properties like mean and variance are constant over time, essential for model stability.', 'Lag (k) - Time delay in an autoregressive model where past data points are used to predict current values.', 'Autoregression Order (p) - The number of lagged terms included in the AR model; higher orders capture more complex dependencies.', 'Autocorrelation Function (ACF) - A tool that measures autocorrelation at different lags, helping determine autoregressive order.', 'Partial Autocorrelation Function (PACF) - Measures partial correlation of a series with its own lagged values after removing the effects of shorter lags.', "Moving Average (MA) - Another component in ARIMA models which captures shocks or innovations; it's often used alongside AR for improved forecasting accuracy.", 'ARIMA model - An integrated autoregressive-moving average time series model that combines differencing with AR and MA components to address non-stationarity.', 'Integrated (I) component - The differencing step in an ARIMA model, applied once to achieve stationarity.', 'Seasonal Autoregression (SAR or SARIMA) - Extends AR models by including seasonality effects; accounts for periodic fluctuations over time.', 'Differencing - A transformation process applied to make a non-stationary series stationary, often used in ARIMA modeling.', 'Residuals - The difference between actual and predicted values from the autoregressive model; ideally should be white noise for validity.', 'Confidence Intervals - Estimates that define a range of values within which we expect the true parameter to fall, used in forecast intervals.', 'Out-of-sample prediction - Forecasting future data points using an autoregressive model on unseen or "test" datasets for validity.', 'Coefficients (alpha, beta) - Parameters derived from ARIMA models that quantify the impact of past values and shocks respectively.', 'Maximum likelihood estimation (MLE) - A statistical method used to estimate the parameters in an autoregressive model by maximizing the likelihood function.', "Likelihood Ratio Test - A hypothesis test comparing two models' fit, useful for selecting between AR and MA components.", 'Box-Jenkins Methodology - A systematic approach of identifying, estimating, and checking time series models including ARIMA.', 'Autocorrelation plot (ACF) - Graphical representation displaying the autocorrelation at different lags; helps in selecting AR order.', 'Partial autocorrelation plot (PACF) - Similar to ACF but for partial correlation, used to determine the appropriate number of AR terms in a model.', 'Model diagnostics - Assessment tools like residual plots and test statistics that help evaluate the adequacy of an autoregressive model fit.', 'Parameter stability - The consistency of estimated parameters over time; critical for reliable long-term forecasting with AR models.', 'Root Mean Square Error (RMSE) - A measure of the differences between values predicted by a model and the actual values, indicating the accuracy of an autoregressive forecast.', "Forecast horizon - The number of future time points for which predictions are made using the ARIMA model; directly impacts the model's complexity and performance."]

['Curtail - to reduce or limit in amount or degree', 'Constrict - to make narrower, smaller, or tighter; also used metaphorically to limit a supply', 'Restrict - to place limitations on the availability of something', 'Curtail - to shorten by cutting off (especially a period of time)', 'Cap - to set a maximum amount that can be produced or consumed', 'Trim - to reduce in size, extent, or quantity; often used in context with supplies', 'Cut down - to decrease the number or amount of something available', 'Minimize - make as small or least in degree or importance; also applies to reducing supply', 'Scale back - to reduce the scale of an activity, which includes limiting its scope and therefore its supply ', 'Ration - to control the size of a food or other supply allowance through fixed distribution', 'Curtail supplies - to shorten the amount available intentionally', 'Limit resources - set boundaries on the availability of natural resources', 'Contain - to keep within bounds, often related to limiting material quantities', 'Conserve - to protect or preserve something by careful use; also implies not exceeding supply', 'Prohibit access to goods/supplies - legally prevent someone from obtaining a certain quantity of items', 'Restrict allocation - control the distribution and amounts of supplies provided ', 'Curtail production - reduce the amount produced, thereby affecting the availability', 'Place caps on output - limit how much is made or distributed', 'Impose quotas - set a legal restriction on the number or quantity that can be supplied', 'Decrease surplus - to lessen excess supplies beyond what is needed or desired']
